channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Russian Planes Will Be Banned From U.S. Airspace
item.description: Explosions struck the capital, Kyiv, near a memorial for a massacre of Jews in World War II, as well as in Ukraine’s second largest city, Kharkiv. President Zelensky accused Russia of war crimes for targeting civilians.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A projectile hit the main radio and television tower in Kyiv, on Tuesday.

item.title: Ukraine War Sets Off Europe’s Fastest Migration in Decades
item.description: At least 660,000 people, mostly women and children, fled Ukraine in the five days after Russia invaded — the most intense wave of European migration since at least the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees on Tuesday at the Ukrainian-Moldovan border.

item.title: U.K. Moves to Tighten Laws on Oligarchs. Critics Say It’s Too Late.
item.description: With most of the Western world uniting against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Britain is trying to plug loopholes for wealthy Russians to which it has long turned a blind eye.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evgeny Lebedev, owner of the London Evening Standard and Independent newspapers, in 2014.

item.title: Mosque Dispute Becomes Flash Point in South Korean Identity Politics
item.description: A mosque dispute in a conservative city has forced some South Koreans to confront what it means to live in an increasingly diverse society.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Muslim students walked by as local Korean residents held signs to protest a proposed new mosque in Daegu, South Korea, in January. “Korean People Come First!” read one of the signs.

item.title: War in Ukraine Hits Home for Taiwanese
item.description: Many in Taiwan see parallels with Ukraine. “We must use this time of peace to prepare for the worst,” says a nonprofit working to promote civil defense.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Demonstrators in front of Russia’s de facto embassy in Taipei in February. For many in Taiwan, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has reinforced their embrace of the island’s democratic values.

item.title: Africans Say Ukrainian Authorities Hindered Them From Fleeing
item.description: Africans and other foreigners in Ukraine say border guards made them endure long waits and even beat them, while letting Ukrainians through quickly. Ukraine denied discriminating.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Ruth Maclean
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Foreigners who were living in Ukraine and are now refugees wait for friends to arrive after crossing into Poland in the town of Medyka on Monday.

item.title: How Ukrainians Are Using Social Media to Speak Out About the War
item.description: Ukrainians take to social media, and taboos are tumbling as countries abandon neutrality and people abandon indifference to support their cause.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: A protest against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in Paris on Saturday.

item.title: As World Rebukes Russia, India Tries to Stay Above the Fray
item.description: A nation isolated in a hostile region increasingly dominated by China, its challenge is to engage the West while not abandoning ties with an old ally.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi and President Vladimir V. Putin in December, when Mr. Putin visited New Delhi.

item.title: Ukraine War Splits Families That Have Roots on Both Sides
item.description: Because of their countries’ complex and intertwined history, many Ukrainians and Russians have relatives who are standing on opposite sides of the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola

item.title: Palestinians Threatened With Eviction Can Stay in Their Homes — for Now
item.description: Israel’s high court stayed the eviction of four Palestinian families from their East Jerusalem homes. The eviction threat had stoked tensions that led to war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: A protest in the East Jerusalem neighborhood of Sheikh Jarrah last week against the threatened evictions of Palestinian families there.

item.title: Ukraine Invasion Increases Friction Between Erdogan and Putin
item.description: The Turkish and Russian leaders have found themselves on opposite sides of a host of armed conflicts. In Ukraine, the stakes may be higher than ever.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, center left, with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, center right, in Moscow in 2020. The two have had a sometimes close, sometimes contentious relationship.

item.title: The One Item They Had to Take When These 6 Afghans Fled
item.description: More than 120,000 people were airlifted out of Afghanistan last August, most with just a few hours to gather their belongings. Here are some of the keepsakes they chose.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Meridith Kohut
item.media:description: Aria Rahmati fled Afghanistan carrying little more than the sapphire and silver ring that had been given to her by a man she cared for.

item.title: Italy Takes a Risk in Joining Sanctions on Russia Over Ukraine
item.description: The two countries have had strong economic ties for decades, but the invasion of Ukraine has spurred the government in Rome to realign with European allies — at an outsize cost.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: A protest against the Russian invasion of Ukraine in Rome on Sunday. Russia could cut off natural gas supplies to Italy in retaliation for sanctions.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Resumes Work After Coronavirus Scare
item.description: The British monarch is feeling well enough to return to her duties, Buckingham Palace said, easing concerns about the 95-year-old’s health.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in Windsor, England, in June. It was unclear where or from whom she had contracted the infection.

item.title: Russia Escalates Attacks on Ukraine as Refugee Numbers Surge
item.description: There was no sign of possible de-escalation on the sixth day of the invasion, as Russia appeared determined to toughen its tactics against a defiant neighbor.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Valerie Hopkins and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marina Shuyeva, 37, visited a monastery in Kyiv on Tuesday to pray for her son and family in Kharkiv.

item.title: Jewish Groups Condemn Strike Near Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial
item.description: It was not clear what damage was done to the memorial but it is close to a radio and television tower in Kyiv that was hit by a projectile.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.category: Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Center (Kyiv, Ukraine)
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Mirror Field monument, part of the Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Site, in Kyiv, Ukraine, last year.

item.title: Russian Casualties Expose a Potential Flaw in Putin’s Strategy
item.description: Videos and photos show the bodies of soldiers left behind on the battlefield, officials say, and the charred remains of tanks and armored vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia visiting the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Moscow last week. Rising military casualties in Ukraine could seriously erode support for Mr. Putin.

item.title: Many Ukrainian Nuclear Power Reactors No Longer Produce Electricity
item.description: Six of the 15 reactors in the country appear to be offline at the moment, with one site close to Russian troop movements reporting half of its reactors are down.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:description: A photo from 2008 of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power complex of six reactors in the town of Enerhodar, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: A Convoy Nears Kyiv
item.description: Plus the U.S. State of the Union and South Korea’s fight over multiculturalism.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A satellite image showing part of a 40-mile-long Russian military convoy near Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Miles-Long Russian Convoy Outside Kyiv Signals Tactical Shift
item.description: Satellite imagery has shown a Russian military convoy stretching 40 miles on a roadway north of Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv. Experts say it probably indicates a shift to siege tactics.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Why Joining the E.U. May Not Be Easy for Ukraine
item.description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is helping to focus minds in Brussels. But the country has big hurdles to overcome before it can join the E.U., the world’s biggest trading bloc.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Ukraine’s ambassador to Belgium, Mykola Tochytskyi, center, applauded on Tuesday after a video address by the country’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, during a special plenary session of the European Parliament in Brussels.

item.title: Workers strike in a London Underground already battered by the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Transport workers in London started the first of two 24-hour strikes planned for this week amid concerns over unfilled posts, pensions and the long-term financing of the rail system.

item.title: Workers Strike in a London Underground Already Battered by the Pandemic
item.description: Transport workers started the first of two 24-hour strikes planned for this week amid concerns over unfilled posts, pensions and the long-term financing of the rail system.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Amanda Holpuch
item.category: National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers (RMT)
item.media:description: A London Underground station was closed on Tuesday amid a systemwide strike by transport workers.

item.title: After Burning for Days, a Ship Carrying Thousands of Luxury Cars Sinks
item.description: The ship, the Felicity Ace, was carrying about 4,000 vehicles, including Bentleys and Porsches, when it caught fire on Feb. 16. On Tuesday morning, it sank.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah and Maria Cramer
item.media:description: The 650-foot-long Felicity Ace car carrier sank off the coast of the Azores on Tuesday, nearly two weeks after it caught fire.

item.title: Some Russian Troops Are Surrendering Rather Than Fighting, Pentagon Says
item.description: A significant number of the Russian troops are young conscripts who are poorly trained and ill-prepared for the all-out assault, a senior official said.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Pro-Russian troops in the separatist-controlled settlement of Mykolaivka, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Ukrainian Invasion Adds to Chaos for Global Supply Chains
item.description: Russia’s military incursion is severing key supply chains and setting off a scramble among global companies to comply with new sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A forklift carried steel sheets at the port in Mykolaiv, Ukraine, last month. The Russian invasion is disrupting global supply chains.

item.title: Gérard Depardieu, Friend of Putin, Denounces ‘Fratricidal War’
item.description: “Stop the weapons and negotiate,” the French actor and staunch Russia ally told a news agency.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Mikhail Klimentyev/Ria-Novosti, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gérard Depardieu greeting President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during a meeting at Mr. Putin’s residence in 2013.

item.title: War in Ukraine Has Investors Thinking About a Second Cold War
item.description: Military conflicts have not been a major factor in market movements for decades. But Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has put global relations back on investors’ minds.
item.dc:creator: Lananh Nguyen
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A line at a bank in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Thursday. The largest military conflict in Europe since World War II has investors watching shifts in international power dynamics more closely.

item.title: Diplomats Walk Out of Lavrov’s U.N. Speech
item.description: Sergey Lavrov accused Ukraine of seeking to acquire nuclear weapons, an unsubstantiated claim that Moscow has used as justification for its invasion.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce

item.title: In Germany, the merging of a protest movement against Covid measures with the far right takes a sinister turn.
item.description: In the former Communist East, security officials worry that a long-running movement against Covid restrictions is becoming an incubator of political violence.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: A recent march against the Covid measures imposed by local and federal governments in Dresden, Germany.

item.title: A Bad Start for Russia
item.description: But many experts are worried about what happens next.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian volunteers file into a bunker in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: U.S. schools are back in person, but many children aren’t back to full time.
item.dc:creator: Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Erica Baber, center, helping her family with schoolwork in Atlanta. Schools there were remote for the first week of 2022 because of a high number of Covid-19 cases in multiple districts.

item.title: The Pfizer vaccine is less effective in 5- to 11-year-olds than in older groups, new data show.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli and Noah Weiland
item.media:description: A 10-year-old received a Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine shot last year in Cranston, R.I.

item.title: Biden will lay out new nursing home protections in his State of the Union speech.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: Nursing home residents waited to receive a Covid-19 vaccine in New York last year.

item.title: Starlink Satellite Internet Terminals, Sent by Elon Musk, Arrive in Ukraine
item.description: Responding to a plea by a Ukrainian official, Mr. Musk delivered an unknown number of his Starlink terminals, which offer online connection via orbiting satellites, bypassing conventional providers.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Craig Bailey/Florida Today, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket lifts off at Kennedy Space Center, Fla., in February, carrying a batch of Starlink satellites.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A bloody attack on Ukraine’s second-largest city.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A destroyed school in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Tech Companies Help Defend Ukraine Against Cyberattacks
item.description: After years of talks about the need for public-private partnerships to combat cyberattacks, the war in Ukraine is stress-testing the system.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes and Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians gather in a train station in Kyiv in an effort to leave the city shortly after the Russian invasion began.

item.title: Chinese Company Removed as Operator of Cobalt Mine in Congo
item.description: A court has given the Congolese control of one of the world’s largest sources of cobalt while allegations against the mine’s Chinese owners are investigated.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton and Dionne Searcey
item.media:description: The court ruling stems from a dispute over billions of dollars the Congolese government says it is owed by the Chinese owner of the Tenke Fungurume mine.

item.title: U.S. Expels 12 Russian Diplomats for Spying
item.description: The move is part of a larger effort to isolate Russia diplomatically and economically since it invaded Ukraine last week.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Rallies in support of Ukraine outside the United Nations headquarters in New York on Monday.

item.title: A Few Members of Russia's Parliament Speak Out Against War
item.description: In a rare show of dissent, three deputies of the State Duma have expressed regret about the attack.
item.dc:creator: Ada Petriczko
item.media:description: People walking in front of the Russian Duma building in Moscow, on February 22.

item.title: Russian Rocket Kills Civilians as First Talks Show No Progress
item.description: The deadly rocket assault on a residential area of Ukraine’s second-largest city signaled an escalation of Russian tactics, and overshadowed efforts at diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Steven Erlanger and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: A destroyed school on Monday in Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: What Questions Do You Have About Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine?
item.description: New York Times reporters will answer reader questions about the war, the world’s response and the effects of sanctions against Russia.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: People took cover in a sports center that became an improvised bomb shelter late Sunday evening, in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: In Miami, a Ukrainian Art Show Becomes Unintentionally Timely
item.description: A Kyiv couple stage a socially charged exhibition in South Florida as their Voloshyn Gallery back home becomes a bomb shelter.
item.dc:creator: Brett Sokol
item.media:credit: Alfonso Duran for The New York Times
item.media:description: An installation view of Julia and Max Voloshyn’s pop-up exhibition of Ukrainian artworks in a Miami warehouse.

item.title: Biden Administration Faces Pressure to Let Ukrainians Stay in U.S.
item.description: Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, has called on the administration to offer Temporary Protected Status to Ukrainians who are on short-term visas or have no documentation.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside the White House to protest against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Ukraine War Tests the Power of Tech Giants
item.description: Google, Meta, Twitter, Telegram and others are levers in the conflict, caught between demands from Ukraine, Russia, the European Union and the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:description: A cellphone user in Moscow. The war in Ukraine has become a defining geopolitical moment for the world’s biggest tech companies.

item.title: Planned Europe-Russia Joint Mars Mission Called “Very Unlikely”
item.description: The ExoMars mission, postponed in 2020 because of the pandemic and technical issues, may miss its window to launch this year because of sanctions imposed against Russia over the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Joey Roulette
item.media:description: A working prototype of the Rosalind Franklin ExoMars rover at the Airbus Defence and Space facility in Stevenage, north of London, in 2019.

item.title: Invasion Brings Russia Global Repudiation With Cold War Echoes
item.description: From culture to commerce, sports to travel, the world is shunning Russia in myriad ways to protest President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aeroflot airplanes at the Sheremetyevo Airport in Moscow on Monday.

item.title: Russians Face Sanctions and Anxieties of a Costly War
item.description: The ruble plunged, the stock market was shuttered and foreign investors shed holdings in Russian companies, deepening the concern among citizens who had become accustomed to the perks of globalization.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a supermarket in Moscow.

item.title: Pakistan Will Cut Energy Prices to Offset Rising Costs After Invasion
item.description: Critics said the move by Prime Minister Imran Khan was aimed at stemming increasing criticism of his handling of the economy and would provide only temporary relief.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Pakistanis at a market in Karachi watched Prime Minister Imran Khan address the nation on Monday.

item.title: Russian Forces Hit Harder in Ukraine After a Fumbled Start
item.description: After days of miscalculation about Ukraine’s resolve to fight, Russian forces are turning toward an old pattern of opening fire on cities and mounting sieges.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with a disabled Russian troop carrier on Friday outside Ukraine’s second-largest city, Kharkiv.

item.title: Fighting Rages On in Ukraine
item.description: Sanctions hit Russia, crushing the ruble.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: A school destroyed in Ukraine near its border with Russia.

item.title: Treasured Paintings Burned in Russian Invasion, Ukrainian Officials Say
item.description: Roughly 25 works by the painter Maria Primachenko were destroyed at a museum in Ivankiv, Ukraine’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Graham Bowley

item.title: Russian Artists Speak Out Against War, but Fear Reprisals
item.description: Two Russian artists have pulled out of the Venice Biennale and thousands are signing antiwar petitions.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Initial Talks Between Russia and Ukraine Yield No Resolution
item.description: Russia’s delegation leader said the next meeting would take place once more along the Ukraine-Belarus border in the “coming days.”
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: In this photograph provided by Belarussian state media, the Russian delegation, on the left, and the Ukrainian delegation, on the right, during negotiations in the Gomel region Monday in Belarus.

item.title: Wales and Scotland Move to Relax Some Covid Restrictions
item.description: Various masking and vaccination rules will ease, though the approach is more gradual than England’s.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Ben Birchall/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The regional government in Wales said it was dropping mask requirements for cinemas and some other indoor public venues. Masked moviegoers were spaced far apart in May at a theater in Cardiff, Wales.

item.title: Pfizer Shot Is Far Less Effective in 5- to 11-Year-Olds Than in Older Kids, New Data Show
item.description: While protection against hospitalization is still strong, the vaccine offered almost no protection against infection, even just a month after full vaccination.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli and Noah Weiland
item.media:description: A 10-year-old receiving the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine at Hartford Hospital in Hartford, Conn.

item.title: Switzerland Says it Will Freeze Russian Assets
item.description: The decision came amid mounting public anger at Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: President Ignazio Cassis of Switzerland addressing a session of the United Nations Human Rights Council, in Geneva, on Monday.

item.title: Zelensky Urges the E.U. to Admit Ukraine Immediately
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: US Escalates Sanctions With a Freeze on Russian Central Bank Assets
item.description: The action is likely to fuel rapid inflation in Russia as it wages war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers in Moscow on Saturday. Senior Biden administration officials predicted inflation in Russia would soon spike and economic activity would contract as the country’s currency lost value.

item.title: Classroom Disruptions
item.description: We look at the surprising number of recent classroom shutdowns in the U.S. And the latest from Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Tomas Ovalle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Noelle Rodriguez moved her hair salon to her home in Fresno, Calif.
